awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating computing in STEM: Designing, developing, and investigating a team-based professional development model for middle- and high-school teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). The goal of this collaborative STEM+Computing project is to design, develop, and investigate outcomes of professional development (PD) designed to support in-service teachers in integrating computing and STEM curricula across middle- and high-school classrooms. Approximately 360 teachers in North Carolina and South Carolina will be recruited to participate in summer PD workshops. In each state, one workshop will implement a new PD model that provides interdisciplinary teams of STEM+C teachers with an opportunity to work with the investigators and together -- in the workshop and throughout the academic year -- to build lessons, activities, and resources that integrate computing into classroom-based activities. These resources will be freely shared with other teachers and the public. A second workshop in each state will employ a more traditional, single-teacher focused approach to PD. Following the workshops, the project will support the teachers year-round through monthly online meetings, and opportunities to participate in an online forum and attend in-person sessions. Investigators from Citadel Military College of South Carolina and North Carolina State University will collaborate to: design and develop the team-based PD; investigate its effects on educational practice; create computational tools as needed to support classroom-based activities; and work to advance knowledge on how the new resources can be effectively adopted across diverse classrooms, contexts, and cultures.

This project will explore how PD contexts (e.g., individual or team) and cultures (discipline, state) impact the quality and implementation of STEM curricula integrated with computing. The PD will be implemented and studied in three phases, with a particular focus on teacher outcomes, utilizing data obtained through administration of extant instrumentation, interviews, focus groups, video and audio recordings of classroom interactions, and analyses of artifacts. Members of the project team will design new integrated STEM+C curricula; develop standards crosswalks; map the curricula to standards; develop, test, and refine tools (including Snap! programming modules that will help students integrate complex computing and STEM content into creative projects); build and support a community of teachers integrating computing in STEM; and conduct a rigorous comparison study across two states (North Carolina and South Carolina), and PD types (individual and team). Standards crosswalks and project research will make explicit connections across state and national STEM standards, computing standards school curricula, and classroom contexts. An independent evaluator will assess: implementation; teachers' reactions to professional learning; changes in teacher content knowledge as a result of professional learning, and implications for classroom instruction; and teachers' attitudes and behaviors, and the extent to which teachers are adopting new computing pedagogies and activities.

por.por_cntn:
The research for this project focused on how to support content area teachers’ integration of computational thinking (CT) through professional development (PD) and ongoing lesson implementation support. Specifically, we investigated how teachers’ learning about CT transformed over time and what CT infusion looks like across multiple content areas (ELA, math, science, social studies, and related arts). Findings from this comparative analysis of teacher learning over time and across content areas revealed distinct differences in terms of the implementation challenges that teachers faced, shifts in their frames of reference regarding the infusion of CT, the form and function of CT infusion in their classrooms, and their understanding and infusion of specific CT concepts. Given the exploratory nature of empirical research on CT integration in different content areas, this perspective provides a much-needed examination of how teachers came to understand CT and utilize it in their disciplinary teaching. While previous CT integration efforts have often focused on supporting STEM teachers, the findings of this study show that CT can be integrated into all content areas. This work also has important implications for designers of professional learning experiences involving CT; for example, including educators from all disciplines, not just STEM areas can expand transformative professional learning experiences that accelerate teachers’ development of knowledge and skills. As part of our work, we developed several tools and models that provide new knowledge for the field, including practical models for virtual and hybrid professional development and theoretical models of CT infusion for content area teachers. For example, as part of the PD design process, we created a mnemonic device (PRADA) to enable teachers to distill their learning and teaching of computational thinking (CT) to four elements: Pattern Recognition, Abstraction, Decomposition, and Algorithms. By using the PRADA CT framework and exploring examples of computing in the classroom, teachers were able to reflect on the ways in which computing and CT connect to existing standards and curricula. Teachers enacted this knowledge while designing lesson plans that infused computing into their teaching. 

Over four years of teacher PD, this project directly impacted over 300 teachers and the thousands of students in their classrooms, resulting in hundreds of CT-integrated lessons. Following the final PD, our work continued with a small group of NC Teachers and HS Interns to create new lessons using the PRADA CT framework. We designed the high school internship program to provide enriching learning experiences for interns while supporting teachers in lesson plan creation and CT learning. Furthermore, the high school interns designed their own CT-integrated lesson plans, demonstrating areas of high school student interests and where high school students see intersections between CT and other disciplines.The lessons were reviewed and improved as necessary for quality, and then added to the CT-integrated lessons library at www.infusingcomputing.com website.
